sci:arg.name: Tempfiles
sci:arg.sci:help:
A comma delimited list of global properties, each of which will automatically hold the name of a file in the job's temporary folder, whose name is guaranteed to be unique.

For each global name, an additional global is created (with the suffix _Filename) that hold just the leaf file name of the temporary file.

sci:arg.name: Protocol Form
sci:arg.sci:help: The path to a protocol that will render an HTML user interface for this protocol. This optional parameter is used by Web Port to provide a custom user interface for a protocol.

sci:arg.name: __PoolID
sci:arg.sci:help:
__PoolID is a case insensitive string that can optionally be set to optimize the speed of execution for quick running protocols. Multiple protocols with the same value for __PoolID can share expensive resources such as database connections, Java VMs, memory, etc. reducing the execution time by 1 to 2 seconds per run. This can give a large speed improvement to protocols that run in a few seconds such as web applications and interactive reports. Longer running protocols will not see much benefit. Generally, it is a good idea to use the same __PoolID for all protocols within a single application such as an interactive report since many of the components, databases, and data structures will be similar.

__PoolID can also be specified by the client when the protocol is launched. If __PoolID is specified both as a parameter by the client and as a parameter stored within the protocol, the client's value overrides the stored value.

To disable pooling entirely for this particular protocol, set __PoolID to <Disable>

sci:arg.name: Http Cookie Handling
sci:arg.sci:help:
Http Cookie Handling provides a mechanism to control the handling of Http cookies within components that access remote resources via Http and Https. These include the HTTP Connector, Data readers such as Text Reader, XML Reader (Generic), etc., and custom Java, Perl, and .Net components that use the available APIs for accessing remote servers. By default, New Protocols will have this setting enabled and set to "Protocol Scope". This means that Http cookies obtained from a remote server within any component in the protocol or any of its subprotocols will be parsed and appropriately sent back on subsequent requests from the same component or any other component. The handling of the cookies is based on the IETF standard as specified in http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6265. Setting the parameter to Disabled will prevent components from parsing and returning cookies to the remote servers.

Persistence of cookies is not supported, so scoping of Http cookies is entirely within the context of a single protocol execution.

Older protocols that do not have the Http Cookie Handling parameter will behave as though it had been set to "Disabled". To enable cookie handling in these protocols, copy this parameter from a New Protocol to the older protocol and set the parameter as desired.

sci:arg.name: __NotificationProtocol
sci:arg.sci:help:
__NotificationProtocol specifies the name or component ID (guid) of a protocol stored in the server's protocol database that will be executed when the current job completes. If your administrator has enabled notification protocols and depending on his or her preference, the notify protocol will either run as the anonymous user or as an admin specified user. The notification protocol receives several parameters that contain information about the original job:

  • Notify_JobID: The job id of the execution
  • Notify_JobStatus: A description of the result of the job execution
  • Notify_JobStatusCode: The status code that for the result of the job execution.
    • 5: Job was stopped by the client or administrator.
    • 6: Job completed normally with success.
    • 7: Job completed with an error.
    • 8: The process ID associated with the running job crashed or otherwise disappeared.
    • 9: Job failed to start.
  • Notify_ProtocolName: The name of the protocol
  • Notify_ProtocolPath: The path of the protocol in the DB. This field can be blank for protocols that were launched without saving to the database.
  • Notify_ProtocolLogName: The log name of the protocol. Is usually the same as ProtocolName, however this can be set by the client to a different name than the protocol.
  • Notify_RunHost: The name of the node where the protocol executed.
  • Notify_Username: The user that ran the job

sci:arg.name: Destination
sci:arg.sci:help:
The name or path name for the destination data. The destination can be a file, a network resource, a data record property, or a global property.
  • Use a network URL for a network resource.
  • Use a file path name for a file.
  • Use "global://property-name" for a global property.

Note:

  • When the destination is a file or network resource, specify an extension such as .txt or .xls. To save in compressed (zipped) format, add the extension .gz or .zip to the filename.

sci:arg.name: Maximum
sci:arg.sci:help: The maximum number of data records to write (all if value is empty)

sci:arg.name: IfFileExists
sci:arg.sci:help: What to do if the given destination file already exists

sci:arg.name: CharacterEncoding
sci:arg.sci:help:
Indicates the character set that to use within the file.

ANSI is the default and specifies a character set where each character is defined by a single byte. This allows the Latin-1 (ISO-8859-1) character set to be written to the file. Virtually all applications can read these files.

UTF-8 specifies a variable length character set. Each character is represented by 1 to 6 bytes. This allows writing out any extended characters specified in the Unicode character sets while minimizing the size of the file. Many applications do not support UTF-8 files.

"Unicode" and "Unicode big endian" are sets where each character is represented by exactly 2 bytes (also known as UCS-2). Determines the order in which the bytes appear for each character. Many applications do not support Unicode or Unicode big endian files.

For more information about each of these encoding styles, go to http://www.unicode.org

sci:arg.name: UseByteOrderMark
sci:arg.sci:help:
The byte order mark (BOM) is an optional Unicode character written to the start of a file or data stream to indicate the character encoding of the following data. Spefically it can be used to indicate the various UTF-8 and UTF-16 encodings.

BOMs are more widely used in a Windows setting. (For example, Windows Notepad includes a BOM in UTF-8 files.)

Setting options are:

Always
For non-ANSI encodings, the BOM is always written at the start of the output stream.
Never
No BOM is written at the start of the output stream.
Native
This is equivalent to "Always" on Windows and "Never" on Linux.

sci:arg.name: Delimiter
sci:arg.sci:help: Specifies the character to use to separate the fields in the file. (Whole records are separated by line breaks.) Make sure you use a different MultiValueDelimiter than Delimiter!

sci:arg.name: MultipleValueDelimiter
sci:arg.sci:help: The delimiter to use between multiple values on a single property. If "None", multiple values are separated into their own columns.

sci:arg.name: UndefinedString
sci:arg.sci:help: Text to output when data for a given column is not present (leave empty or enter text of choice)

sci:arg.name: OutputColumnNames
sci:arg.sci:help: Output column names

sci:arg.name: OutputColumnTypes
sci:arg.sci:help: Output a row that includes column types

sci:arg.name: OutputRowNumber
sci:arg.sci:help: Includes the number of the record as the first field for each record

sci:arg.name: MissingValue Format
sci:arg.sci:help: How to write out explicitly-defined MissingValue properties. Each missing value property contains a string that might indicate the reason the value is missing. You can ask to see either the missing value text containing this string, or use the undefined string to write out missing values.

sci:arg.name: NewlineStyle
sci:arg.sci:help:
Set this value to define the line ending character(s) in the output file. The default value is the Windows-standard carriage return plus line feed (CR+LF), but you might need to change this, especially in a non-Windows environment. Options are:

  • CR+LF (Traditional Windows text file line ending)
  • LF (Line feed, '\n', 0x0A)
  • CR (Carriage return, '\r', 0x0D)
  • Native (CR+LF on Windows, LF on Linux)

sci:arg.name: SourceTag
sci:arg.sci:help:
The type of tag to create to identify the source of data records. A property called SourceTag is created and holds the value indicated.

  • None: No SourceTag property is created and any existing ones are removed.
  • Filename: The name of the file read.
  • FilenameAndExtension: The name of the file read with its file extension.
  • FullFilename: The name of the file read, including the directory path.
  • ZipFilename: When reading a compressed zip file, the filename within the compressed archive.
  • Number: When multiple files are read in this component, they are numbered 1,2,3...
  • Letter: When multiple files are read in this component, they are lettered A, B, C...
  • KeepCurrent: Keeps the current value of SourceTag.

sci:arg.name: Keep Properties
sci:arg.sci:help: A list of properties the reader should retain for each data record that is output. If a value is not defined, retains all properties. If the parameter contains the value "-" (minus sign), properties are not retained.

sci:arg.name: UTF-8 Auto Detect
sci:arg.sci:help:
UTF-8 is a type of character encoding used to represent international characters with multiple bytes whereas basic Latin characters remain as a single byte. Files can be stored with a Byte Order Mark (BOM) to indicate that the type of character encoding.

When reading files that do not have a BOM, this parameter allows the reader to attempt to automatically detect UTF-8 encodings and convert as needed. However, be aware that automatic detection is not always reliable. In some cases, valid text stored in different character encodings can appear to be valid UTF-8. In these cases, the automatic detection will result in garbled text. When this occurs, you can consider using the Binary Reader to read the file, then converting using the Pilotscript function ConvertBytesToString

sci:arg.name: Additional Options
sci:arg.sci:help: Contains less commonly used parameters

sci:arg.name: SD Format Options
sci:arg.sci:help:
Options available for the SD Reader:

  • Properties Can Contain $$$$: By the CTFile standard, a property can contain a '$$$$'-line. Properties or data field values are terminated by a blank line. Only then will the '$$$$'-line terminate the full data block. Setting this option off will terminate the data block upon any read of a '$$$$'-line. This option is available to provide compatibility with some 3rd Party SD files.
  • One-space Lines Terminate Properties: By the CTFile standard, properties or data fields values are terminated by a blank line. Selecting this option will terminate the data block when encountering a line containing a space as the only character in the line. This option is available to provide compatibility with some 3rd Party SD files.
  • Unwrap Long Property Lines: By the CTFile standard, lines in property fields cannot exceed 200 characters. When this option is selected and a property line of exactly 200 characters is found, the newline character will be ignored and property string will continue on the next line.
  • Read Unknown Stereo Parity: When selected, the SD Reader will use the 'Atom Parity' value (parity of '3') to mark unknown stereo centers in 3D mol files. This will leave these atoms marked as 'unknown stereo' and will not calculate the stereo from the coordinates.
  • Process Complex Data Header Lines: Data header lines are the lines in the SD format that precede the actual data. They can contain the data field name (enclosed in angular brackets <>), the data field number (as DTn), the external registry number (enclosed in parentheses), and other optional information. When this parameter is set to False, only the data field name is parsed and used to set the corresponding property name. All the other information in the line is ignored. When the parameter is set to true, all the information is parsed. The property name is set from either the field name in <> or the DTn. If both are present the field name takes priority and the DTn number is saved as an additional property named FieldName#DTn. The external registry number is saved as FieldName#ExtRegNum and any other information is saved as FieldName#OtherDataFieldInfo. When the molecules are written to an SD file, the data header lines are reconstructed from these properties. The default state of this parameter is False, as parsing, preserving, and eventually writing all the information in the data header lines can be costly, specially for SD files with many data fields.
  • Convert From H2 And H+ Atom Types: 'H2' and 'H+' are two non-standard element types that can be assigned to atoms by the BIOVIA Draw sketcher. They represent unattached Hydrogen (a Hydrogen molecule) and charged Hydrogen (a proton), respectively. When this parameter is selected, these atom types are converted to standard hydrogen atoms upon reading, with charges of 0 for H2 and +1 for H+. Otherwise, these atoms are read and perceived as unknown atom types, with 'H2' and 'H+' as the atom labels.
  • Convert Radicals To Pi Systems: When selected, pi bonds will be perceived between adjacent atoms marked with radicals and any adjacent metal atom. Once pi bonds are perceived, subsequent exports will represent the pi bonds using the V3000 format and one-to-many coordination bonds (type 9) unless the writer's Convert Pi Systems To Radicals option is used to convert the pi systems back.
  • Convert GEN+DAT to Polymer Repeat Units: When selected, this option will automatically convert input GEN sgroups with linked DAT sgroups having the special fieldname of 'rc' and numeric or numeric range data internally into polymer repeat sgroups. This usage is a special type of NONS (Non-Specific Structure) convention that was prototyped in previous releases. Disabling this conversion will have a higher likelihood of producing a structure that can be registered into Direct databases.
  • Always Keep Enhanced Stereo: Preserves any enhanced stereo collections that are read in from V3000 MOL file. When disabled, stereo structures will be checked to see if they can be represented more simply using only the Chiral Flag. That is, structures with only ABS centers can be represented without enhanced stereo by setting the Chiral Flag on and structures with all centers in a single AND group can be represented without enhanced stereo by setting the Chiral Flag off. Enhanced stereo collections that do not fit into the above cases are always preserved.
sci:arg.sci:legalval: Convert From H2 And H+ Atom Types
Convert GEN+DAT to Polymer Repeat Units

sci:arg.name: AllowUnknownDoubleBondsFromCoordinates
sci:arg.sci:help: According to the CTfile specifications, the cis/trans character of double bonds with bond stereo set to zero is determined from the coordinates. This parameter controls whether or not to assign unknown bond stereo to double bonds for which the stereo could not be determined from the coordinates, either because there are no coordinates or because of colinearity issues. When the parameter is set to False and the stereo could not be determined, no specific stereo configuration is assigned to the double bond, but it is not marked as unknown stereo.

sci:arg.name: Action
sci:arg.sci:help:
Options for the type of standardization you can perform. The default is to standardize the charging and stereochemistry of the molecule. If multiple actions are selected, they are performed in the given order. Available actions:
  • StandardizeStereo: Atoms that are perceived as true stereo atoms but which have no stereochemical markings (UnknownAtomStereo, EvenAtomStereo, or OddAtomStereo) are set to UnknownAtomStereo. Atoms that have stereochemical markings but which are not true stereoatoms are set to NoAtomStereo. 2D or 3D coordinates are not used in this process.
    Similarly, bonds that are perceived as true stereo double bonds, but which have no stereochemical markings (UnknownBondStereo, CisBondStereo, or TransBondStereo) are set to UnknownBondStereo. Bonds that have stereochemical markings but which are not true stereo bonds are set to NoBondStereo. Again, 2D or 3D coordinates are not used in this process.
  • StandardizeCharges: Sets standard formal charges for common functional groups: Quaternary Nitrogen: +1
    Nitro groups: N+(=O)O-
    Diazonium N: +1
    Oxygen with three attachments: +1
    X=O-C Oxygen: +1
    Sulfur with three attachments: +1
    S=O-C Sulfur: +1
    F, Cl, Br, I with no attachments: -1
    Note that halogen acids with explicit hydrogens (H-X) are not modified.
  • StandardizePiSystems: Checks pi systems to convert them to a kekulized representation with single/double bonds and a net radical or charge (depending on the charge of the connected atom).
  • CenterMolecule: Translates the molecule to the center of geometry.
  • RemoveSingleAtomFragments: Removes all unattached atoms from the molecule.
  • KeepSmallestFragment: Keeps only the fragment with fewer atoms in the case of multifragment molecules.
  • KeepLargestFragment: Keeps only the fragment with the most atoms in the case of multifragment molecules.
  • RemoveLargestFragment: Removes the fragment with the most atoms in the case of multifragment molecules.
  • MakeNon[H]Atoms[C]Atoms: Converts all the atoms in the molecule to Carbon.
  • MakeNon[C,H]Atoms[Q]Atoms: Converts all non-carbon, non-hydrogen atoms in the molecule to the Q query atom type.
  • MakeNon[H]Atoms[A]Atoms: Converts all non-hydrogen atoms in the molecule to the A query atom type.
  • MakeAllBondsSingle: Converts all the bonds in the molecule to Single bonds.
  • ClearCoordinates: Sets all x, y, z coordinates to zero.
  • FixCoordinateDimension: Checks the x, y, z atomic coordinates and sets the dimension for the molecule accordingly:
    • 3 if non-zero values are found for x or y, and for z.
    • 2 if non-zero values are found for x or y, but not for z.
    • 0 if all x, y, z coordinates are zero.
  • StraightenTripleBonds: Looks for triple bonds with non-linear geometry and makes them linear. In some cases this action could cause atoms to overlap each other. This can be checked with the Bump Check Filter and the bumps resolved using the 'Resolve Bumps Only' option in 2D Coords.
  • StraightenAllenes: Looks for allene structures with non-linear geometry and makes them linear. In some cases this action could cause atoms to overlap each other. This can be checked with the Bump Check Filter and the bumps resolved using the 'Resolve Bumps Only' option in 2D Coords.
  • ClearMolecule: Deletes all atoms and bonds in the molecule, keeping the molecule object in the data record.
  • RemoveMolecule: Deletes the molecule object from the data record.
  • ClearStereo: Sets all atoms and bonds to NoStereo.
  • ClearEnhancedStereo: Clears all relative atom stereo groups (enhanced stereo) from the molecule.
  • ClearUnknownStereo: Sets all atoms and bonds that are marked UnknownStereo to NoStereo.
  • ClearUnknownAtomStereo: Sets all atoms that are marked UnknownStereo to NoStereo.
  • ClearUnknownCisTransBondStereo: Sets all bonds that are marked UnknownStereo to NoStereo.
  • ClearUnknownCisTransBondStereoInSmallRings: Sets all bonds in small rings that are marked UnknownStereo to NoStereo. This flag is useful because the SMILES writer suppresses Cis/Trans markings for bonds in small rings.
  • ClearCisTransBondStereo: Sets all bonds that are marked CisStereo or TransStereo to UnknownStereo.
  • ClearCharges: Sets all formal charges to zero.
  • SetStereoFromCoordinates: This option uses the 2D coordinates and up/down bond markings, or the 3D coordinates, to assign the stereochemistry of the atoms or bonds. Typically, this is done by the readers or the molecules from text components. Occasionally, components may create molecules that need to have their stereo reperceived.
  • RepositionStereoBonds: This option repositions the stereo bond markings, trying to find the best bond to mark as a wedge bond for each stereo atom.
  • RepositionAxialStereoBonds: This option repositions the stereo bond markings on axial stereo centers (allenes and atropisomers). This is more expensive than the tetrahedral reposition action as it requires perceiving rings and aromaticity.
  • FixDirectionOfWedgeBonds: This option checks the wedge bonds in the molecule to make sure that the wedge is drawn with the stereo atom at the narrow end of the wedge. Any wedge bond for which there is a stereo atom at the wide end and no stereo atom at the narrow end is reversed to point in the other direction. A separate option, Invert Wedge Bond When Changing Direction, controls whether or not to invert the bond stereo (up or down) when changing the direction of the wedge bond.
  • StandardStereoToEnhancedStereo: Converts structures which contain only standard chiral-flag on or chiral-flag off into structures that contain enhanced stereo groups. If the structure has the chiral flag on, then all stereo centers will be added to a single ABS group. If the structure has the chiral flag off, then all stereocenters will be added to a single AND group.
  • ClearPiBonds: Deletes the pi bonds.
  • ClearQueryInfo: Deletes all query information from atoms and bonds.
  • ClearHighlightColors: Clears any highlight colors from atoms and bonds.
  • ClearAtomLabels: Clears any labels assigned to the atoms.
  • ClearBondLabels: Clears any labels assigned to the bonds.
  • NeutralizeBondedZwitterions: Converts directly bonded zwitterions (positively charged atom bonded to negatively charged atom, A+B-) to the neutral representation (A=B)
  • ClearUnusualValence: Clears any atom valence query features and resets all implicit hydrogen counts to their standard values.
  • ClearIsotopes: Clears any isotope information from the atoms in the molecule, setting all to the most common isotopes.
  • ClearDativeBonds: Clears explicit dative bonds (as found in V3000 mol files).
  • ClearHydrogenBonds: Clears explicit hydrogen bonds (as found in V3000 mol files).
  • LocalizeMarkushRAtomsOnRings: Takes molecules with delocalized R atoms (R atoms pointing to center of the ring) and replaces them with R atoms attached to all available positions in the ring.

Note:

  • To remove sgroups or invalidate their coordinates, use Clear Sgroup Features
sci:arg.sci:member: Invert Wedge Bond When Changing Direction

sci:arg.name: Acids
sci:arg.sci:help:
Specify whether to charge, uncharge or keep the current charge for single-bonded Oxygen atoms in carboxylic, sulfuric and phosphoric acid groups.
This option is enabled only when "StandardizeCharges" is selected in the Action parameter.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: contains(parameter('Action'), 'StandardizeCharges')

sci:arg.name: Single Halogen Atoms
sci:arg.sci:help:
Specify whether to charge, uncharge or keep the current charge for any unconnected halogen atom found in the molecule.
This option is enabled only when "StandardizeCharges" is selected in the Action parameter.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: contains(parameter('Action'), 'StandardizeCharges')

sci:arg.name: Single Metal Atoms
sci:arg.sci:help:
Specify whether to charge, uncharge or keep the current charge for any unconnected metal atom found in the molecule.
This option is enabled only when "StandardizeCharges" is selected in the Action parameter.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: contains(parameter('Action'), 'StandardizeCharges')

sci:arg.name: Normalize Metals in Group 1A
sci:arg.sci:help: When set to True, a covalent bond is defined between positively charged ions in Group 1A (Li+, Na+, K+, Rb+, Cs+) and corresponding counter ions (C-, N-, Si-, P-). Also, covalent bonds between neutral Group 1A elements and neutral halogens or Oxygen are converted into ionic species, breaking the bond and charging the previously attached atoms to create (Li+, Na+, K+, Rb+, Cs+) and (X-, O-).
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: contains(parameter('Action'), 'StandardizeCharges')

sci:arg.name: Mark Unknown Stereo Centers
sci:arg.sci:help: When standardizing stereo, look for true stereo centers missing stereo marks (wedge bonds) and mark them as Unknown Stereo atoms, with their corresponding 'wiggly' bonds.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: contains(parameter('Action'), 'StandardizeStereo')

sci:arg.name: Process Pseudo Stereo Atoms
sci:arg.sci:help: Whether or not to include pseudo stereo atoms not marked with up or down bond wedges (unknown pseudo stereo) when doing "StandardizeStereo" or "SetStereoFromCoordinates".
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: contains(parameter('Action'), 'SetStereoFromCoordinates') or contains(parameter('Action'), 'StandardizeStereo')

sci:arg.name: Preserve Stereo Marks On
sci:arg.sci:help:
Allow wedge bonds on certain atoms with perceived SP2 hybridization:
  • Allenes: Carbon atoms at the end of allene groups.
  • Restricted Biphenyls:Atoms at the ortho positions of geometrically restricted biphenyl or biaryl rings.
  • Conjugated SP2 Nitrogens:Nitrogen atoms with three single bonds which are perceived to be SP2 because of conjugation with neighboring groups.
  • Uncharged Tetrahedral Nitrogens: Normally Pipeline Pilot only recognizes Nitrogen as a tetrahedral stereocenter when it has a positive charge and four heavy attachments. Selecting this parameter will bypass this restriction and mark other Nitrogen stereocenters (such as Nitrogen atoms with three single bonds) as bad only if they fail the check of ambiguous wedge-bond geometry.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: contains(parameter('Action'), 'StandardizeStereo')

sci:arg.name: Invert Wedge Bond When Changing Direction
sci:arg.sci:help: This parameter controls whether or not to invert the bond stereo (up or down) when changing the direction of the wedge bond by selecting "FixDirectionOfWedgeBonds" in the Action parameter.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: contains(parameter('Action'), 'FixDirectionOfWedgeBonds')

sci:arg.name: Remove Explicit Valences
sci:arg.sci:help: Remove explicit valence values from atoms when clearing query infomation
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: contains(parameter('Action'), 'ClearQueryInfo')

sci:arg.name: Track Actions Taken
sci:arg.sci:help: When enabled, this will keep track of which actions resulted in changes to the input molecule. Actions that result in changes will be listed in a property called Standardize_Actions_Taken.

sci:arg.name: ComponentAttributes
sci:arg.sci:help: Component Attributes

sci:arg.name: Standardize Ionizable Groups
sci:arg.sci:help: Transform ionizable groups such as sulphates, phosphates and guanidiniums to a standard form.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: contains(parameter('Action'), 'StandardizeCharges')

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Applies selected predefined actions to input molecules such as standardizing charges or stereo, or the clearing of various attributes

One or more actions can be applied to each molecule to standardize the way molecules are presented to downstream components. See help text on Action for a list and short description of all the available standardization actions.

Standardization is important when comparing molecular libraries from different sources. If different rules were used for structural representation when creating these libraries, a straight comparison would yield incorrect results. The options below allow you to apply a consistent set of rules to structures before comparing them.

sci:arg.name: RegistrationVersion
sci:arg.sci:help: The server version when this component was registered

sci:arg.name: ComponentLocalID
sci:arg.sci:help: Local Component Identifier

sci:arg.sci:help: The original path within the database of this component.

sci:arg.name: Scitegic Salts
sci:arg.sci:help: File that contains the default salt queries

sci:arg.name: User Salts
sci:arg.sci:help: File containing user-defined salt queries

sci:arg.name: Output SMILES of Identified Salts
sci:arg.sci:help: Whether or not to output the SMILES strings of the salts found in the molecule in the property SaltSmiles

sci:arg.name: Match Salt Queries Exactly
sci:arg.sci:help:
Toggles whether to use stricter search options on the internal substructure mapper used to identify salt fragments from the input set of salt queries.


When not enabled, the default salt identification options are used (these are the search options used in older versions of the component):

  • NonChiral Queries Are Enantiomers
  • Uncharged Atoms Can Map Charged Atoms
  • Stereo Atoms Can Map Nonstereo Atoms


When enabled, the following more strict options are used:

  • Chiral Queries Only Map Chiral Targets
  • NonChiral Queries Are Enantiomers
  • Interpret RAtoms Literally
  • Interpret ZAtoms Literally
  • Interpret StarAtoms Literally
  • Check Bonds To RAtoms
  • Match Cis Trans Double Bonds
  • Marked Isotopes Only Map Marked Isotopes
  • Unmarked Isotopes Only Map Unmarked Isotopes

sci:arg.sci:help: The date this component was registered.

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Finds and removes salt fragments from the incoming molecules

Salt fragments in the input molecules are identified using supplied salt queries and removed. The default salt queries are specified by the Scitegic Salts parameter and are contained in the file data/Salts/Scitegic/Salts.sd.

User Salts allows users to add their own salt queries by specifying the file or files containing them. Queries can be defined in either mol format (.mol, .sd, .sdf extension) or SMARTS (.sma extension).

When salts are identified and removed, the property RemovedSalts is defined for the molecule. This array property contains the names of the removed salts. If the same salt fragment was present N times, its name appears N times in the array.

Note:

  • Only molecules consisting of more than one fragment are considered for salt removal.

See Also:

  • To remove salt fragments specifying the salt queries in the input stream instead of reading them from a file, use Strip Salts from Tag.
  • To only identify (and not remove) salt fragments, use Identify Salts.

sci:arg.name: RunToCompletion
sci:arg.sci:help:
When RunToCompletion is set to "True - For Each Data Record", the subprotocol is re-initialized and executed in its entirety for each individual data record it processes.

When set to "True - For Each Category", the data records are divided into categories based on the value of the Categorize Using parameter and then the subprotocol is re-initialized and executed in its entirety for each category of data records. When used in conjunction with Parallel Processing Options, each category of data records will be sent to the remote server as part of one single batch.

sci:arg.name: RunToCompletion Categorize Using
sci:arg.sci:help: Required when RunToCompletion is set to True - For Each Category, this parameter specifies the property or properties used to define the categories.
sci:arg.sci:validscript: SetInvalidDetails('This parameter is required when RunToCompletion is set to True - For Each Category'); Parameter() ne '';
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails('To Enable, Set RunToCompletion to True - For Each Category'); Parameter('RunToCompletion') eq 'True - For Each Category';

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options
sci:arg.sci:help:
When set to True, this set of options allows the subprotocol to execute in parallel on one or more independent Pipeline Pilot servers, running locally or remotely. Additional parameters control the number of data records to send in each process batch, the list of Pipeline Pilot servers to use, the number of protocol processes that can be executed on each server, and whether to preserve the order of the processed data records.

Use this option with care, since it will not increase throughput in all circumstances. Generally speaking, it yields improved performance when the parallelization benefits outweigh the data transfer overhead for the specified batch size. As a rough guide, performance can be improved when each individual batch requires at least 10 seconds to execute, although this can be affected by the size of each data record.

When running the protocol with debugging, the subprotocol will provide debugging messages to detail each of the various steps of execution. Also, components located within the parallel subprotocol will display their debugging messages as well.

For more information on the parallel subprotocol options, see Parallel Processing Subprotocols.

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Batch Size
sci:arg.sci:help:
The number of records to send to the remote server(s) for each subprotocol execution. In general, performance is optimized when the amount of time required to process each batch is at least 10 seconds (note that this can vary depending on the characteristics of the remote server's hardware). Use a batch size of -1 to pass all data in a single batch.

When RunToCompletion is set to "True - for each category", the batch sizes will be determined by the number of records in each individual category. Therefore, the Batch Size parameter is not applicable.

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Server
sci:arg.sci:help:
A comma-separated list of Pipeline Pilot servers on which to execute the parallel subprotocol. The server names should be in the same format as the Pipeline Pilot Client's change server dialog (that is, server-name:port-number).

Specifying localhost as a server will cause the subprotocol to use its own Pipeline Pilot server. This can be useful on multi-CPU/multi-core systems (where the subprotocol jobs are spawned on the same machine) and Pipeline Pilot Linux clusters (where 'localhost' requests spawning the subprotocol jobs on the same cluster).
sci:arg.sci:member: Parallel Processing Options Server Run On Grid
sci:arg.sci:validscript: SetInvalidDetails('This parameter is required.'); Parameter() ne '';
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails("This parameter is only applicable if 'Parallel Processing Options' is 'True'"); Parameter('Parallel Processing Options');

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Server Processes
sci:arg.sci:help: A comma-separated list of the maximum number of batches that can be simultaneously executed on each remote server. The number of entries in this parameter must equal the number of servers. If '*' is specified as the number of processes, then that server will only launch as many batches as the administrator of the remote server has permitted.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails("This parameter is only applicable if 'Parallel Processing Options' is 'True'"); Parameter('Parallel Processing Options');

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Server Run On Grid
sci:arg.sci:help: Run subprotocol on grid engine if available.
sci:arg.sci:member: Parallel Processing Options Server Run On Grid Queue Name
Parallel Processing Options Server Run On Grid Grid Options
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: parameter('Parallel Processing Options');

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Server Run On Grid Queue Name
sci:arg.sci:help: Select the queue name on the grid to submit jobs to. Leave blank to use default queue name.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: parameter('Parallel Processing Options Server Run On Grid');

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Server Run On Grid Grid Options
sci:arg.sci:help: Use this to specify grid engine specific command line parameters to the job submission command. Leave blank to use defaults.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: parameter('Parallel Processing Options Server Run On Grid');

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Preserve Order
sci:arg.sci:help: Whether to preserve the order of the data as it enters and leaves the remote subprotocol.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails("This parameter is only applicable if 'Parallel Processing Options' is 'True'"); Parameter('Parallel Processing Options');

sci:arg.name: Tempfiles
sci:arg.sci:help:
A comma-delimited list of global properties, each of which is automatically populated with the name of a file in the job's temporary folder, which always has a unique name.

For each global name, an additional global is created (with the suffix _Filename) that hold only the leaf file name of the temporary file.

sci:arg.name: DeclareLocal
sci:arg.sci:help:
Lists a set of properties (without the @) to create on the global property list for this subprotocol. Such properties can only be accessed within the scope of this subprotocol and its descendent subprotocols.

Any global property not declared in this way is created on the top-level global property list and is accessible from all subprotocols, but breaks the encapsulation of the subprotocol and may collide with another property of the same name.

Therefore, you should always declare a new global property in the DeclareLocal parameter, to scope the global property to the subprotocol where it is used.

sci:arg.name: PolarAtoms
sci:arg.sci:help:
Select the atoms to be considered polar in the calculation of Molecular_PolarSurfaceArea and Molecular_PolarSASA.
The default setting is to select N, O, P, and S as polar. If a different setting is selected, the selected polar atoms will be appended to the property name. For example, the property name when selecting only N and O as polar atoms will be Molecular_PolarSurfaceArea#NO and Molecular_PolarSASA#NO.

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Calculates surface area, polar surface area (PSA) and volume properties for each molecule

Calculates one or more of the following:

  • Molecular_SurfaceArea: Calculates the total surface area for each molecule using a 2D approximation.
  • Molecular_PolarSurfaceArea: Calculates the polar surface area for each molecule using a 2D approximation.
  • Molecular_FractionalPolarSurfaceArea: The ratio of the polar surface area divided by the total surface area.
  • Molecular_Volume: Calculates the 3D volume for each molecule using the current 3D coordinates. The component will fail if there are no 3D coordinates for the molecule. The 3D Coords and Minimize Molecule components can be used prior to the molecular volume calculation if no 3D coordinates are present for the molecules on the input stream.
  • Molecular_SASA: Calculates the total solvent accessible surface area for each molecule using a 2D approximation.
  • Molecular_PolarSASA: Calculates the polar solvent accessible surface area for each molecule using a 2D approximation. The polar solvent accessible surface area is defined as the sum of the solvent accessible surface area of all the selected polar elements, which can include N, O, P, and S.
  • Molecular_FractionalPolarSASA: The ratio of the polar solvent accessible surface area divided by the total solvent accessible surface area.
  • Molecular_SAVol: Calculates the solvent accessible volume for each molecule using a 2D approximation.

Notes:

  • Solvent accessible surface area and solvent accessible volume are calculated assuming a solvent probe radius of 1.4 Angstroms.
  • The Molecular_SurfaceArea and Molecular_PolarSurfaceArea descriptors are calculated using a method based on the published method: "Fast calculation of molecular polar surface area as a sum of fragment based contributions and its application to the prediction of drug transport properties", Ertl, P., Rohde, B., Selzer, P., J. Med. Chem. 2000, 43, 3714-3717.
  • The solvent-accessible surface area descriptors measure the surface area exposed to a solvent probe. It is based on a 2D approximation which uses models parameterized to reproduce the results obtained with a full 3D calculation using a dot-based method similar to the one originally described in: "Environment and exposure to solvent of protein atoms, lysozyme and insulin", Shrake, A. and Rupley, J.A., J. Mol. Biol., 79, 351-371, 1973.

See Also:

  • To quickly generate 3D coordinates for a molecule, use the 3D Coords or 3D Conformations components.
  • To generate 3D coordinates using the Clean force-field, use the Minimize Molecule component.
  • For more details see the Chemistry Guide Help topic Molecular Surface Area.

sci:arg.sci:help:
ALogP molecule-level properties to calculate. Available properties are:
  • ALogP: The Ghose and Crippen octanol-water partition coefficient.
  • ALogP_MR: The Ghose and Crippen estimate of molar refractivity.
  • ALogP_Count: An array of 120 numbers that correspond to the 120 Ghose and Crippen atom types. The content of each array element is the number of times that particular atom type was seen in the molecule
Output properties can be calculated "on demand" by simply using their names within a PilotScript expression or as the parameter value to many parameters that require a property name.

sci:arg.name: Atom Properties Output
sci:arg.sci:help:
These properties are defined for each atom and are stored in the atom property list. Atom Properties Output specifies which atom-level properties to calculate:
  • ALogP_AtomClass: Integer with the Ghose and Crippen atom type assigned to the atom, a number from 1 to 120.
  • ALogP_AtomClassName: String describing the Ghose and Crippen atom type assigned to the atom (example: "C in CH2R2").
  • ALogP_AtomScore: atomic contribution to the total value of ALogP.
  • ALogP_AtomMRScore: atomic contribution to the total value of AMR.

The Atom Properties component is available for manipulation of atom properties downstream.

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Calculates LogP and Molar Refractivity by the Ghose and Crippen method

Uses the atom-based method published by Ghose and Crippen to calculate the octanol-water partition coefficient (LogP), and the molar refractivity (MR) for the incoming molecules. LogP provides a measure of the hydrophobicity of the molecule, while MR contains information about molecular volume and polarizability.

Output specifies which molecule-level properties to calculate and output for each data record:
  • ALogP: The Ghose and Crippen octanol-water partition coefficient.
  • ALogP_MR: The Ghose and Crippen estimate of molar refractivity.
  • ALogP_Count: An array of 120 numbers that correspond to the 120 Ghose and Crippen atom types. The content of each array element is the number of times that particular atom type was seen in the molecule

Notes:

  • Atom-level properties are also available. These properties are defined for each atom and are stored in the atom property list. Atom Properties Output specifies which atom-level properties to calculate.
  • For more information on the ALogP method see Ghose, A.K., Viswanadhan V.N., and Wendoloski, J.J., Prediction of Hydrophobic (Lipophilic) Properties of Small Organic Molecules Using Fragment Methods: An Analysis of AlogP and CLogP Methods. J. Phys. Chem. A, 1998, 102, 3762-3772.

See Also:

  • To manipulate atomic properties see Atom Properties.
  • To calculate LogD, the octanol-water partition coefficient calculated taking into account the ionization states of the molecule, see logD.

pH value(s) for the calculation of logD.
Input can be a single pH value or a comma-separated set of values. The output for a single pH value is named 'LogD#pH', except when the pH is equal to the default value of 7.4, in which case the name is 'LogD'.
The output for multiple pH values is an array of logD values, with the pH values indicated in the name: 'LogD#pH1,pH2,pH3,pH4,...'

The site example information is used in the calculation of pKa values. This directory contains the original site examples files created by Scitegic during the implementation of the pKa components.

sci:arg.name: pKa Models

sci:arg.name: DerivedFrom
sci:arg.sci:help: The component this component is based upon.

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Calculates logD for the input molecules

Calculates the value of logD, the octanol-water partition coefficient calculated taking into account the ionization states of the molecule.

The name of the output property depends on the value specified for the pH parameter. For pH equals to the default value of 7.4, logD is output as logD. For pH set to any other single value, logD is output as logD#pH, where 'pH' is the pH value. For pH set as a comma-delimited list of values, logD consists of an array of values, one for each pH, and the name of the property is set to logD#pH1,pH2,pH3..., where 'pH1,pH2,pH3' are the pH values.

Notes:

  • The logD calculation utilizes pKa information for each atom in the molecule. Pka sites are located based on the molecular query files located in "data/pKa/AcidBaseSites/". Pka values are calculated based on site examples files located in "data/pKa/Data/" and on PLS Models located in "data/pKa/Models".
  • The AlogP method is used to calculate the logP of each specie.

See Also:

  • pKa for calculation of pKa information for each atom in the molecule
  • Ionize Molecule at pH to transform the molecule according to the calculated pKa values
  • Enumerate Ionization States to enumerate all the possible ionization states of the molecule based on the pKa values and the pH range
  • For details on the pKa and logD calculations, see pKa Calculation User Guide

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Calculates the number of hydrogen acceptors and/or donors

Calculates and outputs the counts of hydrogen bond donors and acceptors in the input molecules. Two properties can be calculated:
  • Num_H_Acceptors: number of heteroatoms (Oxygen, Nitrogen, Sulfur, or Phosphorus) with one or more lone pairs, excluding atoms with positive formal charges, amide and pyrrole-type Nitrogens, and aromatic Oxygen and Sulfur atoms in heterocyclic rings.
  • Num_H_Donors: number of heteroatoms (Oxygen, Nitrogen, Sulfur, or Phosphorus) with one or more attached Hydrogen atoms.
  • Num_H_Acceptors_Lipinski: number of acceptors using Lipinski's simpler convention of counting all Oxygen and Nitrogen atoms as acceptors.
  • Num_H_Donors_Lipinski: the number of OH and NH bonds. Note that primary amines count as two donors.

Note:

  • The calculable properties HBA_Count and HBD_Count, available for use in PilotScript expressions, are defined differently than the properties described above. They are calculated using substructure queries to count the number of times the queries match structural features in the molecule. The substructure queries used to calculate these properties are present in the data/Queries folder:
    • Acceptors: HBA-Nitrogen.mol, HBA-Carboxylate.mol, HBA-Ester.mol, HBA-Ether.mol, HBA-Carbonyl.mol, HBA-Phenol.mol
    • Donors: HBD-PrimaryAlcohol.mol, HBD-PrimaryAmine.mol, HBD-SecondaryAlcohol.mol, HBD-SecondaryAmine.mol, HBD-TertiaryAmine.mol
    Users can change the way hydrogen bond donors and acceptors are counted by adding their own definitions. The only constraint is that the file names should start with the prefix HBA- or HBD-
Records augmented with the calculated properties.

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Calculates whole-molecule properties that are not explicitly "counts"

Calculates the following molecular properties:
  • FormalCharge: The total formal charge of the molecule.
  • CoordDimension: Flag that indicates the type of X,Y,Z coordinates present in the molecule. Possible values are 0 (all coordinates are zero), 2 (2D structure, only X and Y coordinates are defined), and 3 (3D structure, X, Y and Z coordinates are defined).
  • IsChiral: Flag to indicate whether the molecule exists only in the represented absolute stereo configuration (value equals 1) or as a pair of enantiomers (value equals 0). This flag mirrors the Chiral flag in the CTAB format.
  • BondDistance_Table: Calculates the number of bonds in the shortest path between each pairs of atoms in the molecule. The results are output as an array of strings representing the atom-atom distance matrix.
  • AverageBondLength: Calculates the average bond length for the molecule based on the atomic coordinates.

See also:

  • To calculate molecular properties that can be defined as "counts", see Molecular Property Counts.
Records augmented with the specified property or properties

sci:arg.sci:help: Local Component Identifier

sci:arg.sci:help: The original path within the database of this component.

sci:arg.name: Output
sci:arg.sci:help:
The following output properties are in the range of 0 to 1, with 1 being the best:

  • QED: weighted estimate of drug-likeness (or desirability) score, calculated with the weight factors specified in Descriptor Weights.
  • QED_Unweighted: Unweighted estimate of drug-likeness (or desirability) score.
  • QED_MW: molecular weight contribution to the QED score.
  • QED_ALOGP: AlogP contribution to the QED score.
  • QED_HBA: Hydrogen bond acceptor contribution to the QED score.
  • QED_HBD: Hydrogen bond donor contribution to the QED score.
  • QED_PSA: Polar surface area contribution to the QED score.
  • QED_ROTB: Contribution to the QED score from the number of rotatable bonds.
  • QED_AROM: Contribution to the QED score from the number of aromatic rings.
  • QED_ALERTS: Contribution to the QED score from the number of undesirable substructures found in the molecule, which is calculated based on a list of 113 SMARTS queries.

    Note: to calculate this output property, the parameter Include ALERTS Score should be set to true.

These QED output properties can be calculated "on demand" by simply using their names within a PilotScript expression or as the parameter value to a parameter that requires a property name.

sci:arg.name: Include ALERTS Score
sci:arg.sci:help:
Specify whether to map the undesirable substructure queries to count the number present in the molecule and include this term in the QED calculation.

Mapping the undesirable substructures is the most expensive part of the QED calculation, generally taking over 90% of the time. Turning this off speeds up the calculation considerably at the expense of excluding information about undesirable substructures from the resulting QED score. It could be useful to turn it off in a first pass for very large datasets.

sci:arg.name: Descriptor Weights
sci:arg.sci:help: Sets of weights used in the QED calculation

sci:arg.name: Weight_MW
sci:arg.sci:help: Weight factor to apply to the Molecular Weight term

sci:arg.name: Weight_AlogP
sci:arg.sci:help: Weight factor to apply to the AlogP term

sci:arg.name: Weight_HBA
sci:arg.sci:help: Weight factor to apply to the number of hydrogen bond acceptors term

sci:arg.name: Weight_HBD
sci:arg.sci:help: Weight factor to apply to the number of hydrogen bond donors term

sci:arg.name: Weight_PSA
sci:arg.sci:help: Weight factor to apply to the polar surface area term

sci:arg.name: Weight_ROTB
sci:arg.sci:help: Weight factor to apply to the number of rotatable bonds term

sci:arg.name: Weight_AROM
sci:arg.sci:help: Weight factor to apply to the number of aromatic rings term

sci:arg.name: Weight_ALERTS
sci:arg.sci:help: Weight factor to apply to the number of undesirable substructures term
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: parameter("Include ALERTS score") eq true

sci:arg.name: Tempfiles
sci:arg.sci:help:
A comma delimited list of global properties, each of which will automatically hold the name of a file in the job's temporary folder, whose name is guaranteed to be unique.

For each global name, an additional global is created (with the suffix _Filename) that hold just the leaf file name of the temporary file.

sci:arg.name: DeclareLocal
sci:arg.sci:help:
Lists a set of properties (without the @) to create on the global property list for this subprotocol. Such properties can only be accessed within the scope of this subprotocol and its descendent subprotocols.

Any global property not declared in this way is created on the top level global property list and is accessible from all protocols, but may collide with another property of the same name.

Scoping global properties to the subprotocol where they are used is highly recommended.

sci:arg.name: RunToCompletion
sci:arg.sci:help: When RunToCompletion is set to True, the subprotocol is re-initialized and executed in its entirety for each record it processes.

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options
sci:arg.sci:help:
When set to True, this set of options allow the subprotocol to execute in parallel on one or more independent Pipeline Pilot servers, running local or remote. Additional parameters control the number of data records to send in each process batch, the list of Pipeline Pilot servers to use, the number of protocol processes that can be executed on each server, and whether to preserve the order of the processed data records.

Use this option judiciously, since it will not increase throughput in all circumstances. In general, it will yield improved performance when the parallelization benefits outweigh the data transfer overhead for the specified batch size. As a rough guide, performance can be improved when each individual batch requires at least 10 seconds to execute, although this can be affected by the size of each data record.

When running the protocol with debugging, the subprotocol will provide debugging messages to detail each of the various steps of execution. Also, components located within the parallel subprotocol will display their debugging messages as well.

For more information on the parallel subprotocol options, see Parallel Processing Subprotocols.

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Batch Size
sci:arg.sci:help: The number of records to send to the remote server(s) for each subprotocol execution. In general, performance is optimized when the amount of time required to process each batch is at least 10 seconds (note that this can vary depending on the characteristics of the remote server's hardware). Use a batch size of -1 to pass all data in a single batch.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails("This parameter is only applicable if 'Parallel Processing Options' is 'True'"); Parameter('Parallel Processing Options');

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Server
sci:arg.sci:help:
Comma separated list of Pipeline Pilot servers on which to execute the parallel subprotocol. The server names should be in the same format as the Pipeline Pilot Client's change server dialog (server-name:port-number).

Specifying localhost as a server will cause the subprotocol to use its own Pipeline Pilot server. This can be helpful on multi-CPU/multi-core systems (where the subprotocol jobs are spawned on the same machine) and Pipeline Pilot Linux clusters (where 'localhost' requests spawning the subprotocol jobs on the same cluster).
sci:arg.sci:member: Parallel Processing Options Server Run On Grid
sci:arg.sci:validscript: SetInvalidDetails('This parameter is required.'); Parameter() ne '';
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails("This parameter is only applicable if 'Parallel Processing Options' is 'True'"); Parameter('Parallel Processing Options');

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Server Processes
sci:arg.sci:help: Comma separated list of maximum number of batches that can be simultaneously executed on each remote server. The number of entries in this parameter must equal the number of servers. If '*' is specified as the number of processes, then that server will only launch as many batches as the administrator of the remote server has permitted.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails("This parameter is only applicable if 'Parallel Processing Options' is 'True'"); Parameter('Parallel Processing Options');

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Server Run On Grid
sci:arg.sci:help: Run subprotocol on grid engine if available.
sci:arg.sci:member: Parallel Processing Options Server Run On Grid Queue Name
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: parameter('Parallel Processing Options');

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Server Run On Grid Queue Name
sci:arg.sci:help: Select the queue name on the grid to submit jobs to. Leave blank to use default queue name.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: parameter('Parallel Processing Options Server Run On Grid');

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Preserve Order
sci:arg.sci:help: Whether to preserve the order of the data as it enters and leaves the remote subprotocol.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails("This parameter is only applicable if 'Parallel Processing Options' is 'True'"); Parameter('Parallel Processing Options');

The following output properties are in the range of 0 to 1, with 1 being the best:

  • QED: weighted estimate of drug-likeness (or desirability) score, calculated with the weight factors specified in Descriptor Weights.
  • QED_Unweighted: Unweighted estimate of drug-likeness (or desirability) score.
  • QED_MW: molecular weight contribution to the QED score.
  • QED_ALOGP: AlogP contribution to the QED score.
  • QED_HBA: Hydrogen bond acceptor contribution to the QED score.
  • QED_HBD: Hydrogen bond donor contribution to the QED score.
  • QED_PSA: Polar surface area contribution to the QED score.
  • QED_ROTB: Contribution to the QED score from the number of rotatable bonds.
  • QED_AROM: Contribution to the QED score from the number of aromatic rings.
  • QED_ALERTS: Contribution to the QED score from the number of undesirable substructures found in the molecule, which is calculated based on a list of 113 SMARTS queries.

    Note: to calculate this output property, the parameter Include ALERTS Score should be set to true.

These QED output properties can be calculated "on demand" by simply using their names within a PilotScript expression or as the parameter value to a parameter that requires a property name.

sci:arg.sci:value: Calculates the Balaban, Wiener, and Zagreb Index descriptors

The Balaban, Wiener and Zagreb indices are two-dimensional topological descriptors based on graph-theory concepts. They help to differentiate molecules according mostly to their size, degree of branching, flexibility, and overall shape.

See also:

  • Balaban, A. T., "Highly Discriminating Distance-Based Topological Index", Chem. Phys. Lett., 89, 399-404 (1982)
  • Wiener, H., "Structural Determination of Parafin Boiling Points", J. Chem. Phys., 69, 17-20 (1947)
  • Muller, W. R., et al., "An Algorithm for Construction of the Molecular Distance Matrix", J. Comput. Chem., 8, 170-173 (1987)
  • Bonchev, D., "Information Theoretic Indices for Characterization of Chemical Structures", Chemometrics Series, ed. D.D. Bawden, Vol 5, New York: Research Studies Press Ltd. (1983)

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value:
The InfoContent descriptors are two-dimensional topological descriptors. Topological descriptors are based on graph-theory concepts. They help to differentiate molecules according to their size, degree of branching, flexibility, and overall shape.

In this particular approach, molecules are viewed as structures that can be partitioned into subsets of elements that are in some sense equivalent. The notion of equivalence depends on the particular descriptor.

See Also:

  • Bonchev, D., "Information Theoretic Indices for Characterization of Chemical Structures", Chemometrics Series, ed. D.D. Bawden, Vol 5, New York: Research Studies Press Ltd. (1983)

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Calculates Kappa Shape Index descriptors and Molecular Flexibility

The Kier and Hall Shape indices are two-dimensional topological descriptors. Topological descriptors are based on graph-theory concepts. They help to differentiate molecules according mostly to their size, degree of branching, flexibility, and overall shape.

The Kappa Shape Indices compare the molecule graph with "minimal" and "maximal" graphs, where the meaning of "minimal" and "maximal" depends on the order n. This is intended to capture different aspects of the molecular shape.

The Alpha-Modified Kappa Shape Indices are refinements of the above shape indices that take into consideration the contribution covalent radii and hybridization states make to the shape of the molecule.

The Molecular Flexibility a descriptor based on structural properties that restrict a molecule from being "infinitely flexible", the model for which is an endless chain of C(sp3) atoms. The structural features considered as preventing a molecule from attaining infinite flexibility are: (a) fewer atoms, (b) the presence of rings, (c) branching, and (d) the presence of atoms with covalent radii smaller than those of C(sp3).

See Also:

  • Kier, L.B., "A Shape Index from Molecular Graphs", Quant. Struct-Act. Relat., 4, 109-116 (1985)
  • Kier, L. B. "Indexes of molecular shape from chemical graphs" in Computational Chemical Graph Theory; Rouvray, D. H., Ed.; Nova Science: New York (1990).
  • Hall, L.H. and Kier, L.B., "The Molecular Connectivity Chi Indexes and Kappa Shape Indexes in Structure-Property Modeling", in Reviews in Computational Chemistry II., K.B. Lipkowitz and D.B. Boyd, editors, p. 367-422 (1991)(1987)
Molecular Data annotated with shape and/or flexibility descriptors.

sci:arg.name: Component Path
sci:arg.sci:help: The original path within the database of this component.

sci:arg.name: RunToCompletion
sci:arg.sci:help:
When RunToCompletion is set to "True - For Each Data Record", the subprotocol is re-initialized and executed in its entirety for each individual data record it processes.

When set to "True - For Each Category", the data records are divided into categories based on the value of the Categorize Using parameter and then the subprotocol is re-initialized and executed in its entirety for each category of data records. When used in conjunction with Parallel Processing Options, each category of data records will be sent to the remote server as part of one single batch.

sci:arg.name: RunToCompletion Categorize Using
sci:arg.sci:help: Required when RunToCompletion is set to True - For Each Category, this parameter specifies the property or properties used to define the categories.
sci:arg.sci:validscript: SetInvalidDetails('This parameter is required when RunToCompletion is set to True - For Each Category'); Parameter() ne '';
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails('To Enable, Set RunToCompletion to True - For Each Category'); Parameter('RunToCompletion') eq 'True - For Each Category';

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options
sci:arg.sci:help:
When set to True, this set of options allows the subprotocol to execute in parallel on one or more independent Pipeline Pilot servers, running locally or remotely. Additional parameters control the number of data records to send in each process batch, the list of Pipeline Pilot servers to use, the number of protocol processes that can be executed on each server, and whether to preserve the order of the processed data records.

Use this option with care, since it will not increase throughput in all circumstances. Generally speaking, it yields improved performance when the parallelization benefits outweigh the data transfer overhead for the specified batch size. As a rough guide, performance can be improved when each individual batch requires at least 10 seconds to execute, although this can be affected by the size of each data record.

When running the protocol with debugging, the subprotocol will provide debugging messages to detail each of the various steps of execution. Also, components located within the parallel subprotocol will display their debugging messages as well.

For more information on the parallel subprotocol options, see Parallel Processing Subprotocols.

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Batch Size
sci:arg.sci:help:
The number of records to send to the remote server(s) for each subprotocol execution. In general, performance is optimized when the amount of time required to process each batch is at least 10 seconds (note that this can vary depending on the characteristics of the remote server's hardware). Use a batch size of -1 to pass all data in a single batch.

When RunToCompletion is set to "True - for each category", the batch sizes will be determined by the number of records in each individual category. Therefore, the Batch Size parameter is not applicable.

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Server
sci:arg.sci:help:
A comma-separated list of Pipeline Pilot servers on which to execute the parallel subprotocol. The server names should be in the same format as the Pipeline Pilot Client's change server dialog (that is, server-name:port-number).

Specifying localhost as a server will cause the subprotocol to use its own Pipeline Pilot server. This can be useful on multi-CPU/multi-core systems (where the subprotocol jobs are spawned on the same machine) and Pipeline Pilot Linux clusters (where 'localhost' requests spawning the subprotocol jobs on the same cluster).
sci:arg.sci:member: Parallel Processing Options Server Run On Grid
sci:arg.sci:validscript: SetInvalidDetails('This parameter is required.'); Parameter() ne '';
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails("This parameter is only applicable if 'Parallel Processing Options' is 'True'"); Parameter('Parallel Processing Options');

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Server Processes
sci:arg.sci:help: A comma-separated list of the maximum number of batches that can be simultaneously executed on each remote server. The number of entries in this parameter must equal the number of servers. If '*' is specified as the number of processes, then that server will only launch as many batches as the administrator of the remote server has permitted.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails("This parameter is only applicable if 'Parallel Processing Options' is 'True'"); Parameter('Parallel Processing Options');

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Server Run On Grid
sci:arg.sci:help: Run subprotocol on grid engine if available.
sci:arg.sci:member: Parallel Processing Options Server Run On Grid Queue Name
Parallel Processing Options Server Run On Grid Grid Options
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: parameter('Parallel Processing Options');

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Server Run On Grid Queue Name
sci:arg.sci:help: Select the queue name on the grid to submit jobs to. Leave blank to use default queue name.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: parameter('Parallel Processing Options Server Run On Grid');

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Server Run On Grid Grid Options
sci:arg.sci:help: Use this to specify grid engine specific command line parameters to the job submission command. Leave blank to use defaults.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: parameter('Parallel Processing Options Server Run On Grid');

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Preserve Order
sci:arg.sci:help: Whether to preserve the order of the data as it enters and leaves the remote subprotocol.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails("This parameter is only applicable if 'Parallel Processing Options' is 'True'"); Parameter('Parallel Processing Options');

sci:arg.name: Tempfiles
sci:arg.sci:help:
A comma-delimited list of global properties, each of which is automatically populated with the name of a file in the job's temporary folder, which always has a unique name.

For each global name, an additional global is created (with the suffix _Filename) that hold only the leaf file name of the temporary file.

sci:arg.name: DeclareLocal
sci:arg.sci:help:
Lists a set of properties (without the @) to create on the global property list for this subprotocol. Such properties can only be accessed within the scope of this subprotocol and its descendent subprotocols.

Any global property not declared in this way is created on the top-level global property list and is accessible from all subprotocols, but breaks the encapsulation of the subprotocol and may collide with another property of the same name.

Therefore, you should always declare a new global property in the DeclareLocal parameter, to scope the global property to the subprotocol where it is used.

sci:arg.name: Action
sci:arg.sci:help:
Specifies the Hydrogen fill mode:

Adds explicit hydrogens to the molecule. Options include:

  • AddHydrogens: Add hydrogens to all atoms.
  • AddHeteroHydrogens: Add hydrogens just to heteroatoms.
  • AddStereoHydrogens: Add hydrogens just to stereoatoms. Explicit Hydrogens are only added to stereoatoms in which all the atoms attached to the chiral center are in rings or the attached atoms are also stereocenters. Adding these hydrogens often avoids having to put a wedge bond on a ring bond or on a bond to another stereoatom.
  • AddBridgeHeadHydrogens: Add hydrogens to any bridgehead atom.

sci:arg.sci:value:
Adds explicit hydrogens to the molecule. Options include:

  • AddHydrogens: Add hydrogens to all atoms.
  • AddHeteroHydrogens: Add hydrogens just to heteroatoms.
  • AddStereoHydrogens: Add hydrogens just to stereoatoms. Explicit Hydrogens are only added to stereoatoms in which all the atoms attached to the chiral center are in rings or the attached atoms are also stereocenters. Adding these hydrogens often avoids having to put a wedge bond on a ring bond or on a bond to another stereoatom.
  • AddBridgeHeadHydrogens: Add hydrogens to any bridgehead atom.

See Also:

  • To remove explicit hydrogens, use Remove Hydrogens.

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Generates 3D coordinates for the input molecules

Calculates three-dimensional atomic coordinates for each incoming molecule and assigns them to the molecule, discarding any existing original coordinates, either 2D or 3D.

The coordinates are calculated by dividing the molecule into chains and ring systems, generating 3D coordinates for each fragment and putting them together. A few cycles or energy minimization are carried out at the end to clean up the structure and remove any bumps.

See also:

  • To optimize the 3D coordinates to minimize the molecular energy, see Minimize Molecule.
  • To generate different 3D conformations of the molecule, see 3D Conformations.

sci:arg.name: Output
sci:arg.sci:help:
Identifies the values to store with a molecule:
  • Energy: Energy of structure prior to minimization.
  • Minimized_Energy: Energy of minimized structure.
  • Strain_Energy: Difference between the two.

sci:arg.name: MaximumNumberOfSteps
sci:arg.sci:help: The maximum number of minimization steps to perform.

sci:arg.name: ConvergenceEnergyDifference
sci:arg.sci:help: The energy difference between minimization steps required for convergence.

sci:arg.name: UpdateCoords
sci:arg.sci:help: Updates the molecular coordinates after minimization is calculated

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Generates energy minimized coordinates for each input molecule

Uses the Clean force-field to generate minimized coordinates for the input molecules. The property Minimized_Energy, with the value of the energy at the end of the minimization, is added to the property list of each molecule.

Notes:

  • Minimization starts from the current 3D coordinates, if there are any present on the input molecule. If the molecule has no 3D coordinates, an initial 3D conformation is generated and minimized.
  • The Clean force field used in the minimization is described in "Receptor Surface Models. 1. Definition and Construction". Mathew Hahn; J. Med. Chem.; 1995; 38(12); 2080-2090.

See Also:

  • To generate 3D conformations, see 3D Conformations.
Minimized molecules with minimized energy values added

sci:arg.sci:help: The original path within the database of this component.
sci:arg.sci:value: Components\Chemistry\Data Access and Manipulation\Manipulators\3D Methods\Minimize Molecule

sci:arg.name: Output
sci:arg.sci:help:
• Molecular_3D_SASA: Calculates the total solvent accessible surface area for each molecule using a 3D method.
  • Molecular_3D_PolarSASA: Calculates the polar solvent accessible surface area for each molecule using a 3D method. Atoms considered polar are N, O, P, S, hydrogens attached to them, and any atom with a formal charge.
  • Molecular_3D_SAVol: Calculates the solvent accessible volume for each molecule using a 3D method.

Output properties can be calculated "on demand" by simply using their names within a PilotScript expression or as the parameter value to many parameters that require a property name.

sci:arg.name: Probe Radius
sci:arg.sci:help: The radius of the probe to use in the 3D solvent-accessible surface area calculation. The default value is 1.40, which corresponds to a water molecule probe.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: parameter("Use_3DMethod") eq true;

sci:arg.name: Resolution
sci:arg.sci:help: Specifies the number of points in the surface of the atomic spheres used in the 3D solvent-accessible surface area calculation method. Options are Low (100 points), Medium (250 points) or High (500 points)
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: parameter("Use_3DMethod") eq true;

sci:arg.name: Atomic Radii
sci:arg.sci:help:
Van der Waals radii to use for the atoms in the molecule. They should be entered as a comma-separated string with the element symbol followed by ':' followed by the radius. For example:
H:1.10,C:1.55,N:1.40,O:1.35

Note:

  • The default van der Waals radii defined internally by Pipeline Pilot will be used for any element not found in the list.

sci:arg.name: DerivedFrom
sci:arg.sci:help: The component this component is based upon.

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Calculates solvent accessible surface areas and volume using a 3D method

Calculates one or more of the following:

  • Molecular_3D_SASA: Calculates the total solvent accessible surface area for each molecule using a 3D method.
  • Molecular_3D_PolarSASA: Calculates the polar solvent accessible surface area for each molecule using a 3D method. Atoms considered polar are N, O, P, S, hydrogens attached to them, and any atom with a formal charge.
  • Molecular_3D_SAVol: Calculates the solvent accessible volume for each molecule using a 3D method.

Note:

  • Component uses the Jurs algorithm for determining solvent-accessible surface area (SASA). D.T. Stanton and P.C. Jurs. Development and use of charged partial surface area structural descriptors in computer assisted quantitative structure property relationship studies. Anal. Chem., 62:2323-2329, 1990

See Also:

  • To quickly generate 3D coordinates for a molecule, use the 3D Coords or 3D Conformations components.
  • To generate 3D coordinates using the Clean force-field, use the Minimize Molecule component.
Data records augmented with the calculated properties

sci:arg.sci:help: The component this component is based upon.

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Calculates the Principal Moments of Inertia

Calculates the principal moments of inertia about the principal axes of a molecule according to the following rules:
  1. The moments of inertia are computed for a series of straight lines through the center of mass.
  2. Distances are established along each line proportional to the reciprocal of the square root of I on either side of the center of mass. The locus of these distances forms an ellipsoidal surface. The principal moments are associated with the principal axes of the ellipsoid.
  3. If all three moments are equal, the molecule is considered to be a symmetrical top. If no moments are equal, the molecule is considered to be an unsymmetrical top.

See Also:

  • Hill, T.L., Introduction to Statistical Thermodynamics, Addison-Wesley: Reading, MA (1960).
Output molecules with calculated principal moments of inertia properties
