sci:arg.name: Type
sci:arg.sci:help:
The type of fingerprint to generate:
  • ExtendedConnectivity: Generates higher-order features.
  • Path: Generates higher-order features.
  • AtomEnvironment: Generates higher-order features using a method developed by Bender et al. This generates a String Fingerprint.
  • HashedAtomEnvironment: Uses a hash code to create an Integer Fingerprint representation of the AtomEnvironment fingerprints for ease of use (e.g. learned models, etc.).
  • UserKeys: Fingerprints derived from user-defined substructures. These substructure queries are stored in MOL or SD query format in "data\Queries\UserQueries"

Notes:

  • For more information on Extended-Connectivity fingerprints, see Rogers, D. and Hahn, M, Extended-Connectivity Fingerprints. J. Chem. Inf. Model. 2010, 50(5), 742-754
  • For more information on AtomEnvironment fingerprints, see Bender, A., Mussa, H.Y., and Glen, R.C., Molecular Similarity Searching Using Atom Environments, Information-Based Feature Selection, and a Naive Bayesian Classifier. J. Chem. Inf. Comput. Sci. 2004, 44, 170-178
  • The MDLPublicKeys fingerprint previously found here is a native Pipeline Pilot implementation of the MDL fingerprint which does not always match the results obtained from legacy-MDL products such as the Direct Cartridge. This fingerprint has been deprecated in favor of an implementation using MDL libraries which is available in the MDL Key Fingerprints component as the MDL2DKeys166 descriptor. MDLPublicKeys is now available only as a calculable property (i.e. pilotscript: calculate("MDLPublicKeys");)

sci:arg.name: AtomAbstraction
sci:arg.sci:help:
Method used to assign initial category for atom classes.
  • AtomType: (First letter: "E") Uses atom type, charge and hybridization.
  • ALogPCode: (First letter: "L") Uses ALogP category of atoms.
  • FunctionalClass: (First letter: "F") Uses the following groups:
    • H-bond acceptor
    • H-bond donor
    • Positive ionizable
    • Negative ionizable
    • Halogen
    • Aromatic
    • None of the above
  • Sybyl: (First letter: "S") Uses the Sybyl atom types used in the Tripos Mol2 File Format.
  • UserAtomTypes: (First letter: "U") Assumes that the property UserAtomTypes is defined on the molecule, and contains an array of integers, one for each atom in the molecule. The i'th value in the array is the user atom type for the i'th atom in the molecule.
  • Reaction: (First letter: "R") Uses type, charge, hybridization, reactant or product, and "reaction site" information. Atoms are in the reaction site if they are changed by the reaction or attached to bonds that change. This information is perceived from the the reaction's atom-atom mappings. Only reaction site atoms are selected to be bit centers but atoms outside the site can be included for higher-distance bits. Can only be used for reaction inputs.
  • ReactionSiteOnly: (First letter: "Q") Similar to Reaction (see above). Only reaction site atoms are selected to be bit centers and atoms outside the reaction site are excluded from any higher-distance bits. Can only be used for reaction inputs.

See Also:

  • Information about Sybyl atom types is available from Tripos: http://www.tripos.com/mol2/atom_types.html.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails('This parameter does not apply to MDLPublicKeys or UserKeys'); Parameter('Type') ne 'MDLPublicKeys' and Parameter('Type') ne 'UserKeys'

sci:arg.name: MaximumDistance
sci:arg.sci:help:
The maximum bond distance in the substructures represented in the fingerprint.
  • For extended connectivity fingerprints, this is the diameter of the neighborhood surrounding the central atom, and should be an even number.
  • For path fingerprints, this is the maximum number of bonds in the paths.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails('This parameter does not apply to MDLPublicKeys or UserKeys'); Parameter('Type') ne 'MDLPublicKeys' and Parameter('Type') ne 'UserKeys'

sci:arg.name: OutputType
sci:arg.sci:help:
Controls the way the fingerprint is presented:
  • Fingerprint: A list of the features present in the molecule, with duplicates removed.
  • Counts: A list of the features present in the molecule, with duplicates retained; if a feature occurs more than once in a molecule, that bit value is included more than once in the output list.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails('This parameter does not apply to MDLPublicKeys or UserKeys'); Parameter('Type') ne 'MDLPublicKeys' and Parameter('Type') ne 'UserKeys'

sci:arg.name: Options
sci:arg.sci:help:
Options for the fingerprint calculation. IncludeStereo changes the fingerprint. The other options cause the calculation of other properties with associated information. The options are:
  • IncludeStereo: (#S) include information from stereoatoms into fingerprint calculation.
  • OutputBitDistance: (#D) output an array with the length or diameter of each bit.
  • OutputBitSubstructure: (#C) output an array with an example of SMARTS of the fragment.
  • OutputBitExactSubstructure: (#X) output an array with the SMARTS of the fragment, in this molecule. (This is slower than OutputBitSubstructure, since the former can cache the first example it finds in a data set, and re-use it.)
  • OutputBitAllAtoms: (#A) output an array with the set of all atoms involved with a feature anywhere in the molecule.
  • OutputBitFeatureAtoms: (#F) output an array with the set of atoms showing one example of the feature bit.
  • OutputBitCentralAtom: (#Z) output an array with the number of the central atom for each bit.
  • AddBitsToCentralAtom: (#P) output, to each central atoms's property collection, a list of its generated bits. (The atom property name is the name of the fingerprint.)

sci:arg.name: UserKeyDirectory
sci:arg.sci:help:
If given, use this directory (instead of "data/Queries/UserQueries/") for the source of the user keys. The name of the directory must end in a slash or backslash. Note:
  • The substructure queries defined here must be in either MOL or SD query format.
  • The "ReadQueryInfo" parameter on the internal SD reader is enabled to allow the import of any non-CTAB atom and bond tests persisted in the property block.

sci:arg.sci:help: The component this component is based upon.

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Calculates a variety of molecular and reaction fingerprints

Uses one the following algorithms to calculate fingerprints on input molecules and reactions:
  • SciTegic extended-connectivity fingerprints
  • Daylight-style path fingerprints
  • Fingerprints derived from user-defined substructures. These substructure queries are stored in MOL or SD query format in "data\Queries\UserQueries".
For both the extended-connectivity and path fingerprints, a number of methods are available to define the atom abstraction used to generate the initial atom code. You should also specify the maximum path distance (such as number of bonds) that will be used to index an individual fragment.
Records augmented with the molecular fingerprint property

sci:arg.name: RegistrationVersion
sci:arg.sci:help: The server version when this component was registered

sci:arg.name: ComponentLocalID
sci:arg.sci:help: Local Component Identifier

sci:arg.name: Component Path
sci:arg.sci:help: The original path within the database of this component.

sci:arg.name: Type
sci:arg.sci:help:
The type of fingerprint to generate:
  • ExtendedConnectivity: Generates higher-order features.
  • Path: Generates higher-order features.
  • AtomEnvironment: Generates higher-order features using a method developed by Bender et al. This generates a String Fingerprint.
  • HashedAtomEnvironment: Uses a hash code to create an Integer Fingerprint representation of the AtomEnvironment fingerprints for ease of use (e.g. learned models, etc.).
  • UserKeys: Fingerprints derived from user-defined substructures. These substructure queries are stored in MOL or SD query format in "data\Queries\UserQueries"

Notes:

  • For more information on Extended-Connectivity fingerprints, see Rogers, D. and Hahn, M, Extended-Connectivity Fingerprints. J. Chem. Inf. Model. 2010, 50(5), 742-754
  • For more information on AtomEnvironment fingerprints, see Bender, A., Mussa, H.Y., and Glen, R.C., Molecular Similarity Searching Using Atom Environments, Information-Based Feature Selection, and a Naive Bayesian Classifier. J. Chem. Inf. Comput. Sci. 2004, 44, 170-178
  • The MDLPublicKeys fingerprint previously found here is a native Pipeline Pilot implementation of the MDL fingerprint which does not always match the results obtained from legacy-MDL products such as the Direct Cartridge. This fingerprint has been deprecated in favor of an implementation using MDL libraries which is available in the MDL Key Fingerprints component as the MDL2DKeys166 descriptor. MDLPublicKeys is now available only as a calculable property (i.e. pilotscript: calculate("MDLPublicKeys");)

sci:arg.name: AtomAbstraction
sci:arg.sci:help:
Method used to assign initial category for atom classes.
  • AtomType: (First letter: "E") Uses atom type, charge and hybridization.
  • ALogPCode: (First letter: "L") Uses ALogP category of atoms.
  • FunctionalClass: (First letter: "F") Uses the following groups:
    • H-bond acceptor
    • H-bond donor
    • Positive ionizable
    • Negative ionizable
    • Halogen
    • Aromatic
    • None of the above

Atoms are in the reaction site if they are changed by the reaction or attached to bonds that change. This information is perceived from the the reaction's atom-atom mappings. Only reaction site atoms are selected to be bit centers but atoms outside the site can be included for higher-distance bits. Can only be used for reaction inputs.
  • ReactionSiteOnly: (First letter: "Q") Similar to Reaction (see above). Only reaction site atoms are selected to be bit centers and atoms outside the reaction site are excluded from any higher-distance bits. Can only be used for reaction inputs.

See Also:

  • Information about Sybyl atom types is available from Tripos: http://www.tripos.com/mol2/atom_types.html.

  • Sybyl: (First letter: "S") Uses the Sybyl atom types used in the Tripos Mol2 File Format.
  • UserAtomTypes: (First letter: "U") Assumes that the property UserAtomTypes is defined on the molecule, and contains an array of integers, one for each atom in the molecule. The i'th value in the array is the user atom type for the i'th atom in the molecule.
  • Reaction: (First letter: "R") Uses type, charge, hybridization, reactant or product, and "reaction site" information. Atoms are in the reaction site if they are changed by the reaction or attached to bonds that change. This information is perceived from the the reaction's atom-atom mappings. Only reaction site atoms are selected to be bit centers but atoms outside the site can be included for higher-distance bits. Can only be used for reaction inputs.
  • ReactionSiteOnly: (First letter: "Q") Similar to Reaction (see above). Only reaction site atoms are selected to be bit centers and atoms outside the reaction site are excluded from any higher-distance bits. Can only be used for reaction inputs.

See Also:

  • Information about Sybyl atom types is available from Tripos: http://www.tripos.com/mol2/atom_types.html.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails('This parameter does not apply to MDLPublicKeys or UserKeys'); Parameter('Type') ne 'MDLPublicKeys' and Parameter('Type') ne 'UserKeys'

sci:arg.name: MaximumDistance
sci:arg.sci:help:
The maximum bond distance in the substructures represented in the fingerprint.
  • For extended connectivity fingerprints, this is the diameter of the neighborhood surrounding the central atom, and should be an even number.
  • For path fingerprints, this is the maximum number of bonds in the paths.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails('This parameter does not apply to MDLPublicKeys or UserKeys'); Parameter('Type') ne 'MDLPublicKeys' and Parameter('Type') ne 'UserKeys'

sci:arg.name: OutputType
sci:arg.sci:help:
Controls the way the fingerprint is presented:
  • Fingerprint: A list of the features present in the molecule, with duplicates removed.
  • Counts: A list of the features present in the molecule, with duplicates retained; if a feature occurs more than once in a molecule, that bit value is included more than once in the output list.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails('This parameter does not apply to MDLPublicKeys or UserKeys'); Parameter('Type') ne 'MDLPublicKeys' and Parameter('Type') ne 'UserKeys'

sci:arg.name: Options
sci:arg.sci:help:
Options for the fingerprint calculation. IncludeStereo changes the fingerprint. The other options cause the calculation of other properties with associated information. The options are:
  • IncludeStereo: (#S) include information from stereoatoms into fingerprint calculation.
  • OutputBitDistance: (#D) output an array with the length or diameter of each bit.
  • OutputBitSubstructure: (#C) output an array with an example of SMARTS of the fragment.
  • OutputBitExactSubstructure: (#X) output an array with the SMARTS of the fragment, in this molecule. (This is slower than OutputBitSubstructure, since the former can cache the first example it finds in a data set, and re-use it.)
  • OutputBitAllAtoms: (#A) output an array with the set of all atoms involved with a feature anywhere in the molecule.
  • OutputBitFeatureAtoms: (#F) output an array with the set of atoms showing one example of the feature bit.
  • OutputBitCentralAtom: (#Z) output an array with the number of the central atom for each bit.
  • AddBitsToCentralAtom: (#P) output, to each central atoms's property collection, a list of its generated bits. (The atom property name is the name of the fingerprint.)

sci:arg.name: UserKeyDirectory
sci:arg.sci:help:
If given, use this directory (instead of "data/Queries/UserQueries/") for the source of the user keys. The name of the directory must end in a slash or backslash. Note:
  • The substructure queries defined here must be in either MOL or SD query format.
  • The "ReadQueryInfo" parameter on the internal SD reader is enabled to allow the import of any non-CTAB atom and bond tests persisted in the property block.

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Calculates a variety of molecular and reaction fingerprints

Uses one the following algorithms to calculate fingerprints on input molecules and reactions:
  • SciTegic extended-connectivity fingerprints
  • Daylight-style path fingerprints
  • Fingerprints derived from user-defined substructures. These substructure queries are stored in MOL or SD query format in "data\Queries\UserQueries".
For both the extended-connectivity and path fingerprints, a number of methods are available to define the atom abstraction used to generate the initial atom code. You should also specify the maximum path distance (such as number of bonds) that will be used to index an individual fragment.
Records augmented with the molecular fingerprint property

sci:arg.name: RegistrationVersion
sci:arg.sci:help: The server version when this component was registered

sci:arg.name: ComponentLocalID
sci:arg.sci:help: Local Component Identifier

sci:arg.name: Component Path
sci:arg.sci:help: The original path within the database of this component.

sci:arg.name: Type
sci:arg.sci:help:
The type of fingerprint to generate:
  • ExtendedConnectivity: Generates higher-order features.
  • Path: Generates higher-order features.
  • AtomEnvironment: Generates higher-order features using a method developed by Bender et al. This generates a String Fingerprint.
  • HashedAtomEnvironment: Uses a hash code to create an Integer Fingerprint representation of the AtomEnvironment fingerprints for ease of use (e.g. learned models, etc.).
  • UserKeys: Fingerprints derived from user-defined substructures. These substructure queries are stored in MOL or SD query format in "data\Queries\UserQueries"

Notes:

  • For more information on Extended-Connectivity fingerprints, see Rogers, D. and Hahn, M, Extended-Connectivity Fingerprints. J. Chem. Inf. Model. 2010, 50(5), 742-754
  • For more information on AtomEnvironment fingerprints, see Bender, A., Mussa, H.Y., and Glen, R.C., Molecular Similarity Searching Using Atom Environments, Information-Based Feature Selection, and a Naive Bayesian Classifier. J. Chem. Inf. Comput. Sci. 2004, 44, 170-178
  • The MDLPublicKeys fingerprint previously found here is a native Pipeline Pilot implementation of the MDL fingerprint which does not always match the results obtained from legacy-MDL products such as the Direct Cartridge. This fingerprint has been deprecated in favor of an implementation using MDL libraries which is available in the MDL Key Fingerprints component as the MDL2DKeys166 descriptor. MDLPublicKeys is now available only as a calculable property (i.e. pilotscript: calculate("MDLPublicKeys");)

sci:arg.name: AtomAbstraction
sci:arg.sci:help:
Method used to assign initial category for atom classes.
  • AtomType: (First letter: "E") Uses atom type, charge and hybridization.
  • ALogPCode: (First letter: "L") Uses ALogP category of atoms.
  • FunctionalClass: (First letter: "F") Uses the following groups:
    • H-bond acceptor
    • H-bond donor
    • Positive ionizable
    • Negative ionizable
    • Halogen
    • Aromatic
    • None of the above
  • Sybyl: (First letter: "S") Uses the Sybyl atom types used in the Tripos Mol2 File Format.
  • UserAtomTypes: (First letter: "U") Assumes that the property UserAtomTypes is defined on the molecule, and contains an array of integers, one for each atom in the molecule. The i'th value in the array is the user atom type for the i'th atom in the molecule.
  • Reaction: (First letter: "R") Uses type, charge, hybridization, reactant or product, and "reaction site" information. Atoms are in the reaction site if they are changed by the reaction or attached to bonds that change. This information is perceived from the the reaction's atom-atom mappings. Only reaction site atoms are selected to be bit centers but atoms outside the site can be included for higher-distance bits. Can only be used for reaction inputs.
  • ReactionSiteOnly: (First letter: "Q") Similar to Reaction (see above). Only reaction site atoms are selected to be bit centers and atoms outside the reaction site are excluded from any higher-distance bits. Can only be used for reaction inputs.

See Also:

  • Information about Sybyl atom types is available from Tripos: http://www.tripos.com/mol2/atom_types.html.

  • OutputBitFeatureAtoms: (#F) output an array with the set of atoms showing one example of the feature bit.

sci:arg.name: RunToCompletion
sci:arg.sci:help:
When RunToCompletion is set to "True - For Each Data Record", the subprotocol is re-initialized and executed in its entirety for each individual data record it processes.

When set to "True - For Each Category", the data records are divided into categories based on the value of the Categorize Using parameter and then the subprotocol is re-initialized and executed in its entirety for each category of data records. When used in conjunction with Parallel Processing Options, each category of data records will be sent to the remote server as part of one single batch.

sci:arg.name: RunToCompletion Categorize Using
sci:arg.sci:help: Required when RunToCompletion is set to True - For Each Category, this parameter specifies the property or properties used to define the categories.
sci:arg.sci:validscript: SetInvalidDetails('This parameter is required when RunToCompletion is set to True - For Each Category'); Parameter() ne '';
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails('To Enable, Set RunToCompletion to True - For Each Category'); Parameter('RunToCompletion') eq 'True - For Each Category';

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options
sci:arg.sci:help:
When set to True, this set of options allows the subprotocol to execute in parallel on one or more independent Pipeline Pilot servers, running locally or remotely. Additional parameters control the number of data records to send in each process batch, the list of Pipeline Pilot servers to use, the number of protocol processes that can be executed on each server, and whether to preserve the order of the processed data records.

Use this option with care, since it will not increase throughput in all circumstances. Generally speaking, it yields improved performance when the parallelization benefits outweigh the data transfer overhead for the specified batch size. As a rough guide, performance can be improved when each individual batch requires at least 10 seconds to execute, although this can be affected by the size of each data record.

When running the protocol with debugging, the subprotocol will provide debugging messages to detail each of the various steps of execution. Also, components located within the parallel subprotocol will display their debugging messages as well.

For more information on the parallel subprotocol options, see Parallel Processing Subprotocols.

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Batch Size
sci:arg.sci:help:
The number of records to send to the remote server(s) for each subprotocol execution. In general, performance is optimized when the amount of time required to process each batch is at least 10 seconds (note that this can vary depending on the characteristics of the remote server's hardware). Use a batch size of -1 to pass all data in a single batch.

When RunToCompletion is set to "True - for each category", the batch sizes will be determined by the number of records in each individual category. Therefore, the Batch Size parameter is not applicable.

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Server
sci:arg.sci:help:
A comma-separated list of Pipeline Pilot servers on which to execute the parallel subprotocol. The server names should be in the same format as the Pipeline Pilot Client's change server dialog (that is, server-name:port-number).

Specifying localhost as a server will cause the subprotocol to use its own Pipeline Pilot server. This can be useful on multi-CPU/multi-core systems (where the subprotocol jobs are spawned on the same machine) and Pipeline Pilot Linux clusters (where 'localhost' requests spawning the subprotocol jobs on the same cluster).
sci:arg.sci:member: Parallel Processing Options Server Run On Grid
sci:arg.sci:validscript: SetInvalidDetails('This parameter is required.'); Parameter() ne '';
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails("This parameter is only applicable if 'Parallel Processing Options' is 'True'"); Parameter('Parallel Processing Options');

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Server Processes
sci:arg.sci:help: A comma-separated list of the maximum number of batches that can be simultaneously executed on each remote server. The number of entries in this parameter must equal the number of servers. If '*' is specified as the number of processes, then that server will only launch as many batches as the administrator of the remote server has permitted.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails("This parameter is only applicable if 'Parallel Processing Options' is 'True'"); Parameter('Parallel Processing Options');

sci:arg.name: Tempfiles
sci:arg.sci:help:
A comma-delimited list of global properties, each of which is automatically populated with the name of a file in the job's temporary folder, which always has a unique name.

For each global name, an additional global is created (with the suffix _Filename) that hold only the leaf file name of the temporary file.

sci:arg.name: DeclareLocal
sci:arg.sci:help:
Lists a set of properties (without the @) to create on the global property list for this subprotocol. Such properties can only be accessed within the scope of this subprotocol and its descendent subprotocols.

Any global property not declared in this way is created on the top-level global property list and is accessible from all subprotocols, but breaks the encapsulation of the subprotocol and may collide with another property of the same name.

Therefore, you should always declare a new global property in the DeclareLocal parameter, to scope the global property to the subprotocol where it is used.

For more information on the parallel subprotocol options, see Parallel Processing Subprotocols.

Tip: Any component can be made into a shortcut, so that the latest version is always used. For more information, see Creating Shortcuts.

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Applies a PilotScript expression to each data record

PilotScript is the native scripting language in Pipeline Pilot. It is based on PL/SQL and allows you to query or alter the properties on data records. For example, the expression:

A := 10;
creates a property named "A" and sets the value to "10".

For each incoming data record the PilotScript statements in Expression are evaluated.

Notes:

  • To initialize global variables such as counters, use Initial Expression.
  • To clean up global variables or calculate final results use Final Expression.
  • Parameters on Custom Manipulators do not become global variables that can be accessed via @ParameterName syntax. They must be accessed by using the Parameter('ParameterName') function or by using token substitution via $(ParameterName) syntax.

See Also:

  • For more information on PilotScript, see PilotScript Overview.
  • To use PilotScript to filter data records use Custom Filter (PilotScript).

sci:arg.name: RegistrationVersion
sci:arg.sci:help: The server version when this component was registered

sci:arg.name: ComponentLocalID
sci:arg.sci:help: Local Component Identifier

sci:arg.name: Component Path
sci:arg.sci:help: The original path within the database of this component.

sci:arg.name: Expression
sci:arg.sci:help: Expression (or list of expressions separated by semi-colons) to evaluate.

sci:arg.name: Initial Expression
sci:arg.sci:help:
This expression is executed only the first time data passes into the component.

Since there is no data available at initialization time, only expressions referencing local or global properties are allowed.

sci:arg.name: Final Expression
sci:arg.sci:help:
This expression is executed only at finalization (after the last data passes out of the component).

Since there is no data available at finalization time, only expressions referencing local or global properties are allowed.

sci:arg.name: Keep Calculated Properties
sci:arg.sci:help: Adds any properties calculated in this component to a data record's property list.

sci:arg.name: ComponentAttributes
sci:arg.sci:help: Component Attributes

sci:arg.name: OnDataTypeError
sci:arg.sci:help: When an expected data type is not found during processing: Halt: Terminate the execution of the network Fail: Continue execution of the network, passing data out the Fail(red) port Pass: Continue execution of the network, passing data out the Pass(green) port

sci:arg.name: OnGeneralError
sci:arg.sci:help: When an recoverable error occurs during processing: Halt: Terminate the execution of the network Fail: Continue execution of the network, passing data out the Fail(red) port Pass: Continue execution of the network, passing data out the Pass(green) port

sci:arg.name: CustomErrorText
sci:arg.sci:help: Custom Error Message

sci:arg.name: Do Screen
sci:arg.sci:help: When TRUE, controls which exit port is used for each data record by evaluating the final expression (or only one) listed in the "Expression" parameter. -Pass (green) port when expression true -Fail (red) port when expression false

sci:arg.name: ExpressionVersion
sci:arg.sci:help: Version of expression parser to use.

sci:arg.name: Registrant
sci:arg.sci:help: The user who registered this component.

sci:arg.name: RegistrationDate
sci:arg.sci:help: The date this component was registered.

sci:arg.name: ComponentAutoDisplayName
sci:arg.sci:help: Automatically update the component display name when the "Expression" property is changed. This feature is turned off after the user manually changes the display name of the component in Protocol workspace.

sci:arg.name: DerivedFrom
sci:arg.sci:help: The component this component is based upon.

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Applies a PilotScript expression to each data record

PilotScript is the native scripting language in Pipeline Pilot. It is based on PL/SQL and allows you to query or alter the properties on data records. For example, the expression:

A := 10;
creates a property named "A" and sets the value to "10".

For each incoming data record the PilotScript statements in Expression are evaluated.

Notes:

  • To initialize global variables such as counters, use Initial Expression.
  • To clean up global variables or calculate final results use Final Expression.
  • Parameters on Custom Manipulators do not become global variables that can be accessed via @ParameterName syntax. They must be accessed by using the Parameter('ParameterName') function or by using token substitution via $(ParameterName) syntax.

See Also:

  • For more information on PilotScript, see PilotScript Overview.
  • To use PilotScript to filter data records use Custom Filter (PilotScript).

sci:arg.name: Freeze Table Header
sci:arg.sci:help:
When set to True, this table's header and title will remain visible when the table is scrolled vertically.

Notes:

  • This feature only applies to HTML reports.
  • The fixed header behavior depends on what container (e.g., plain browser window, Tile component, Dynamic Content Container) that the Table is piped into.
  • To create a table of fixed pixel height, set this parameter to True and pipe this table into a Dynamic Content Container of fixed (i.e., non-percentage) height.

sci:arg.name: Use Default Browser
sci:arg.sci:help:
This parameter is only relevant when running the protocol in the Pipeline Pilot Professional Client.

The value specifies whether to use your default desktop web browser to view the HTML table. When set to False, Internet Explorer is used as a standard fallback option. If IE is your default browser, it is used in either case.

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Displays data records as HTML in a web browser

Generates and displays an HTML table page of data records, with one record per row. Each property becomes a column in the table and each value a cell.

Notes:

  • Molecules will be displayed if present.
  • For hierarchical data records, only top level properties are displayed.
  • Any grouped data is displayed in nested tables.
See Also:
  • If you prefer not to view the grouped data, use Delete Children.
  • For more control over the display of molecules, use HTML Molecular Table Viewer.

sci:arg.name: Counter Property
sci:arg.sci:help: The name of the property to hold the data record count. If the name begins with "@", this is a global property name and is updated each time a data record is received. Otherwise, it is a local property name and a new property by that name will be created on each data record and given the current value (i.e., the count).
sci:arg.sci:member: Check if Property Already in Use

sci:arg.name: Start Index
sci:arg.sci:help: The index (i.e., number) used to start the sequence.

sci:arg.name: Check if Property Already in Use
sci:arg.sci:help: Generates an error if the property already exists. This helps prevent overwriting data created by another component. Default is "True".

sci:arg.name: DerivedFrom
sci:arg.sci:help: The component this component is based upon.

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Counts the number of data records and puts the count in a property

Use this component to create a numerical index of data records and to keep track of the total number of records. The value of Counter Property is incremented each time a data record enters the component.

This component can be used in two modes:

  • If Counter Property is the name of a local property (does not start with "@"), a new property by that name is created on each data record and given the value of the current count.
  • If Counter Property is the name of a global property (starts with "@"), then each data record that passes through causes this global record count to be incremented, but values are not added to the passing records.

sci:arg.name: Destination
sci:arg.sci:help:
The name or path name for the destination data. The destination can be a file, a network resource, a data record property, or a global property.
  • Use a network URL for a network resource.
  • Use a file path name for a file.
  • Use "global://property-name" for a global property.

Note:

  • When the destination is a file or network resource, specify an extension such as .txt or .xls. To save in compressed (zipped) format, add the extension .gz or .zip to the filename.

sci:arg.name: Maximum
sci:arg.sci:help: The maximum number of data records to write (all if value is empty)

sci:arg.name: IfFileExists
sci:arg.sci:help: What to do if the given destination file already exists

sci:arg.name: CharacterEncoding
sci:arg.sci:help:
Indicates the character set that to use within the file.

ANSI is the default and specifies a character set where each character is defined by a single byte. This allows the Latin-1 (ISO-8859-1) character set to be written to the file. Virtually all applications can read these files.

UTF-8 specifies a variable length character set. Each character is represented by 1 to 6 bytes. This allows writing out any extended characters specified in the Unicode character sets while minimizing the size of the file. Many applications do not support UTF-8 files.

"Unicode" and "Unicode big endian" are sets where each character is represented by exactly 2 bytes (also known as UCS-2). Determines the order in which the bytes appear for each character. Many applications do not support Unicode or Unicode big endian files.

For more information about each of these encoding styles, go to http://www.unicode.org

sci:arg.name: UseByteOrderMark
sci:arg.sci:help:
The byte order mark (BOM) is an optional Unicode character written to the start of a file or data stream to indicate the character encoding of the following data. Spefically it can be used to indicate the various UTF-8 and UTF-16 encodings.

BOMs are more widely used in a Windows setting. (For example, Windows Notepad includes a BOM in UTF-8 files.)

Setting options are:

Always
For non-ANSI encodings, the BOM is always written at the start of the output stream.
Never
No BOM is written at the start of the output stream.
Native
This is equivalent to "Always" on Windows and "Never" on Linux.

sci:arg.name: Delimiter
sci:arg.sci:help: Specifies the character to use to separate the fields in the file. (Whole records are separated by line breaks.) Make sure you use a different MultiValueDelimiter than Delimiter!

sci:arg.name: MultipleValueDelimiter
sci:arg.sci:help: The delimiter to use between multiple values on a single property. If "None", multiple values are separated into their own columns.

sci:arg.name: UndefinedString
sci:arg.sci:help: Text to output when data for a given column is not present (leave empty or enter text of choice)

sci:arg.name: OutputColumnNames
sci:arg.sci:help: Output column names

sci:arg.name: OutputColumnTypes
sci:arg.sci:help: Output a row that includes column types

sci:arg.name: OutputRowNumber
sci:arg.sci:help: Includes the number of the record as the first field for each record

sci:arg.name: MissingValue Format
sci:arg.sci:help: How to write out explicitly-defined MissingValue properties. Each missing value property contains a string that might indicate the reason the value is missing. You can ask to see either the missing value text containing this string, or use the undefined string to write out missing values.

sci:arg.name: NewlineStyle
sci:arg.sci:help:
Set this value to define the line ending character(s) in the output file. The default value is the Windows-standard carriage return plus line feed (CR+LF), but you might need to change this, especially in a non-Windows environment. Options are:

  • CR+LF (Traditional Windows text file line ending)
  • LF (Line feed, '\n', 0x0A)
  • CR (Carriage return, '\r', 0x0D)
  • Native (CR+LF on Windows, LF on Linux)

Data records are separated with a new line and the individual properties within each record are separated with the character specified by Delimiter. The property names for the fields are stored as the first line of the file.

Note:

  • Use MultipleValueDelimiter to control the output format for properties with more than one value (array properties).
